titleStmt.title: Letter from Florence Henniker to Thomas Hardy — 11 August 1914 (H.3175)

physDesc.p: Folded cream card with a printed black border and oval crest “The Little Orchard, Shoreham, Kent.” in black on the first page. Written throughout in a soft grey hand, with extensive cross-writing in the margins and at right angles to the main text.

profileDesc.abstract: Florence Henniker thanks Hardy for his letter and a poem in the Sphere, comments on contemporary verse and war poetry, reflects on cinema and performing animals, notes recent animal-protection measures, and describes rural life and birds in her orchard at Shoreham.

handDesc.handNote: Rapid, slightly right-sloping cursive hand in grey pencil or pale ink; cross-writing in margins and between lines at 90 degrees to the main text.

profileDesc.note: Florence Henniker (1855–1923), novelist and close friend of Thomas Hardy, writes from “The Little Orchard”, Shoreham, during the opening year of the First World War, discussing literature, animal welfare, and her rural surroundings.

notesStmt.note: Four-page card, black-ruled border on first page only; printed oval “The Little Orchard. Shoreham. Kent.” at head. Later pencil docket “Hon Mrs Henniker” appears at upper margin in another hand.

projectDesc.p: Diplomatic transcription with line breaks preserved and cross-writing encoded in .

bibl.title: Letter from Florence Henniker to Thomas Hardy
bibl.creator: Florence Henniker

opener.dateline:
The Little Orchard, Shoreham, Kent.
Aug 11. 14

body.p: Best thanks for your last nice long letter, full of news. Also very many thanks for the fine poem in the "Sphere". There are beautiful lines in it, but of course it is very sad. I have not seen the magazine conducted by the "uppish" young poets. Possibly there may be good things in it now & again, for as Mr. Gosse thinks there is a great deal of almost good verse published. I think Miss Wedmore’s is very much above the ordinary, don’t you? and I see that a story by Mr. Arthur Bell is very much praised.

I was really impressed by Frank Tayfin’s "The Gallant Way". They are of course soldiers’ poems, & they have a splendid ring & go about them — one on "Minden" — another on "Blucher" — & a 3rd about "The Men" themselves.
body.seg: (margin, upper right) How Mrs Henniker is appearing so much younger than her years; very kindly of you to ask about my health — it is shaky, but the air I think very bracing.
(margin, upper left) The politician in old days, that he now very seldom reads your books; but he thinks they would stand time.
body.p: I think Miss Wedmore’s verse much above the ordinary; don’t you? and I see that a story by Mr Arthur Bell is very much praised. I was really impressed by Frank Taplin’s "The Gallant Way". They are of course soldiers’ poems & they have a splendid ring & go — one on "Minden" — another on "Blucher" — & a 3rd about "The Men".

There are a few things that have happened lately which cheer one. The passing of the plumage bill in America & the stopping of the feathers from the hats of certain women delights me. But I fear the inspection of the ponies is very unsatisfactory — & Mr. McKenna has behaved badly about it. I hope you are getting fond of this live "Wessex"?
This place, as I think I told you, is quite astonishingly rural. In some of the country roads & lanes one might be a hundred miles from London, instead of 23.
body.seg: (top margin) One hears that "Hardy & Meredith" are beyond dispute the two great names.
body.p: What do you think of this craze for films? I see you say "Far from the madding crowd" is to be done. I wonder if the system makes people lazy about reading, & less keen about genuine drama?

I am so glad you have written about performing animals. There may be a few cases in which they are kindly treated, & learn tricks easily (such as Milner’s); but the whole thing is liable to dreadful abuses & cruelties.

There are a few birds that have already taken to us, which cheers one. The plumage bill in America, & the stopping of the feathers from the hats of certain women, delights me, as I said. I hope you are feeling fairly well.
I hope to do a great deal in encouraging birds in the orchard. Please give many messages to Miss Drysdale, & my love. Some day you & she must come & see me here.
The other day I went to a little party at the boys’ — the two Sergeants that first had them; they were so kind in getting up interesting talk to come & talk to me of it.
body.seg: (margin) Brands & I also went to hear his lecture on "Hamlet" some day. He is an excellent critic, you know. (Valfrè-Guild?) I must tell you of it another time.
